awd_titl_txt: SusChEM: Design Principles Inspired by Symmetry for Controlling Singlet Fission in Structurally Well-Defined Covalent Dimers
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamic & Mechanism B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professors Niels H. Damrauer and Tarek Sammakia of the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at the University of Colorado Boulder are synthesizing new organic molecular systems that contain two chromophores (i.e., parts of the molecules that can absorb light) and using spectroscopy to explore their photophysics. The goal is to develop design rules for how the arrangement of the chromophores controls excited state reactivity following visible light photoexcitation. The particular reaction of interest is important in certain next-generation strategies to increase the efficiency of solar cells by limiting waste heat production that generally occurs when higher energy solar photons are absorbed. This proposal establishes a fundamental research program where students are exposed to a considerable breadth of ideas in synthesis, spectroscopy, and applications of electronic structure theory. A specific outreach effort in collaboration with local high school teachers is part of the funded work that aims to provide sophisticated but affordable spectroscopic tools and curriculum ideas to Colorado high school science programs. 

Singlet fission is a photophysical phenomenon observed in certain organic materials wherein light absorption produces a spin-allowed singlet excited state that then non-radiatively converts to a pair of triplet excitations. If these triplets can be further transformed to charge carriers, it is possible to envision device scenarios where the solar spectrum is more efficiently utilized compared to devices in operation today. This research is predicated on the idea that molecular dimers are the fundamental unit for singlet fission and that they can provide a platform wherein synthetic manipulations that control the spatial juxtaposition and covalent interaction of chromophores are called upon to affect key photophysical rate constants. The most important design opportunity that is being tested relates to dimer point group symmetry and the idea that it can control the interference (constructive vs. destructive) of pathways in the quantum mechanical description of diabatic coupling for singlet fission. Other strategies will call on substituents to affect the relative energy of charge transfer states.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: This project explored the synthesis of new organic molecules that contain two chromophores (i.e., parts of the molecules that can absorb light) connected to each other in a well-defined geometry and with a particular symmetry, and the study  of these molecules in relation to  a  photophysical process called singlet fission. Singlet fission is a phenomenon that can be initiated in certain types of molecules built with specific energetic properties. First, a   single photon of light is absorbed by a chromophore, resulting in electronic excitation (one electron is promoted to a higher energy state but other electrons also respond to this). In many chromophores, what happens next is relaxation of this excess electronic energy resulting in the emission of light or in the release of heat. But in singlet fission, the energy is shared with a neighboring chromophore resulting in the production of a set of two electronic excitations, one on each chromophore. The splitting of the energy is the reason for calling it fission, even when it has nothing to do with nuclear power. These sets of excitations  can, in principle, be used in photovoltaic devices, allowing for the more efficient harvesting of light for the production of electricity. The details of the geometrical and energetic constraints for the molecules that undergo singlet fission are the key ingredients to designing improved systems that may ultimately serve in practical settings. The goal of this project was to better understand both of these and we chose a structural platform that, while synthetically challenging, could give high quality information about the origins of singlet fission reaction control, owing to the structural definition of the systems and how that allows one to interpret spectroscopic results. We were successful in our synthetic efforts and learned, along the way, how to make a variety of conformationally rigid molecules for this study, achieving difficult transformations and overcoming challenging physical properties of the synthetic intermediates, such as poor solubility and chemical instability. We then studied these molecules using laser-based spectroscopic methods to determine the rate and extent of singlet fission. We had predicted that molecules with a certain type of symmetry would be slow to undergo fission, but were surprised to find that this was not the case! We attribute this behavior to vibrations that occur and break the symmetry such that electrons that are predicted to not communicate well with each other can couple and undergo the needed energy transfer in singlet fission. We also found, as predicted, that molecules with a greater driving force to undergo singlet fission did, in fact, undergo the process to a greater extent. However, we also saw limits to this, where too much energy released in the process begins to slow it.  More importantly/generally, we showed with the broader class of molecules synthesized in the project, that a small set of controllable parameters, ones that are central to modern theories about reaction rates, are the key knobs to control the speed and efficiency of the singlet fission reaction. 

Broader Impacts: The scientific broader impacts of this project include teaching the chemical community how to synthesize the class of molecules (bridged bicyclic bis-acene derivatives) on which these studies were predicated, and the importance of considering specific physical properties of intermediates in a multi-step synthesis. Our spectroscopic studies point to a deeper fundamental understanding of electronic coupling with applications not just in singlet fission, but in related energy transfer processes. This project also allowed for a very broad training of undergraduate and graduate students in the synthesis of complex organic molecules, their spectroscopic studies, and applications to electronic structure theory. In addition, Professors Damrauer and Sammakia engaged in outreach efforts to promote STEM disciplines.  A nascent collaboration with DSST, a Denver-based network of schools with a focus on STEM education, was established with a goal of providing sophisticated, but affordable, spectroscopic tools based on 3D printed components designed by the group, a cell phone camera, and free processing software, to advanced high school students targeting those from groups underrepresented in STEM. In addition, Professors Sammakia and Damrauer participated in the CU Wizards program where they gave science demonstrations to a target audience of elementary and middle school-aged students and their parents.

 


Last Modified: 02/09/2022
Modified by: Niels H Damrauer
